choices.B: Create a blocking policy based on the parameter values.
choices.C: Change the parameter name 'Account_Name' identified in the log.
choices.D: Create an alert to generate emails for abnormally high activity.
choices.A: Alert the web server administrators to a misconfiguration.

discussion.content: common sense : B

comments.content: the most important question : can a WAF bloc traffic based on the parameter value in D . if yes then answer D is correct

discussion.content:
D makes sense. The log entry only indicates that a SQL infection was attempted. No where in the question is it indicated that the query was successful in producing results.
The Security Administrator is auditing the server and has it behind a WAF to monitor activity. 
The next logical step would be to monitor for successful SQL injection attempts, which if effective would produce high data volume traffic over the network across the WAF
Definitely B. Nothing in the information provided would indicate unusually high volume.
I don’t even know what is going on. Please I need help on this question

I am looking it at this way. If parameters can be blocked then as an attacker I can change the same and try with different parameters. For option A, there might not be a misconfiguration but an attacker might be probing using SQL injection. As of now, I have set up email notification, to generate alert if there is an abnormally high activity of the same type. Hence, they might have chosen that as an answer. Again, I might be wrong.

If you were to work through the problem it would be best to stop the attempt or future attempt as it is not a vulnerability but rather an exploit since it was evident in the audit log. With that thinking you would want to B. create blocking policy and then A. let the web admin know. I'm not unsure of the wording with B? Would it be a way to stop SQL injection by blocking parameter values?

comments.content: Or A.. not sure which one..
Definitely SQL injection... A and B could both be right...
OK I think it's B, web server admins need to do input validation to make sure these types of attacks don't work.

Pretty sure it's B.

comments.content: A violation of time of day restrictions would result in a failed login attempt. I have actually configured time of day restrictions for user accounts. A 7-day grid appears with 24 rows and 7 columns. The administrator just clicks on the hours on the days where login is allowed. That policy is not a measurable metric. A violation of that policy would result in a failed login. Failed logins is a measurable metric.
TIME of Day is correct but not for above stated reason! It simply divides shift employees into their respective shifts! kinda stupid question!
Don't listen to Melvin he knows nothing and keeps changing answers trying to confuse people.
Think so too

Why not?
The keyword here is "shift workers", create groups for different shifts and implment time-of-day restrictions - makes sense.

discussion.content: A. "Management wants to monitor group performance." So needs a metric to measure, like the number of failed logon attempts. Time-of-day restrictions is not a measurable item.

questions.question_text: A call center company wants to implement a domain policy primarily for its shift workers. The call center has large groups with different user roles. Management wants to monitor group performance. Which of the following is the BEST solution for the company to implement?

choices.C: reduced key strength due to salt manipulation.
choices.A: loss of data caused by unauthorized command execution.
choices.B: privilege escalation caused by TPM override.

discussion.content:
It was a typo. its TPM.
A Trusted Platform Module (TPM) is a specialized chip on an endpoint device that stores RSA encryption keys specific to the host system for hardware authentication. ... The term TPM is sometimes used in reference to the set of specifications applicable to TPM chips

comments.content:
As you stated "This vulnerability is CAUSED BY A HARDWARE DESIGN PROBLEM", which implies it's not caused buffer overflow.

I found the article describing the Privilege escalation via unchecked TPM reset vulnerability, and this article doesn't mention anything about buffer overflow.
https://www.chromium.org/chromium-os/unchecked_tpm_reset

After reading all discussions, I'm still can't be convinced that the answer is A. So confused. Could someone explain further why A is correct? Thanks

I know that that buffer overflow can result in arbitrary CODE execution, but not sure if it's able to cause COMMAND execution. I believe there's a difference between these two. If A were "unauthorized code execution", I would definitely vote for A. Can't decide which one is correct based on my limited knowledge.

discussion.content:
Answer is B.
Privilege escalation via unchecked TPM reset. This vulnerability is caused by a hardware design problem specific to a small faction of device models resulting in the main CPU being able to trigger a reset of the TPM while the main CPU doesn't reset.

Selected Answer: A
Buffer overflows typically have a high severity ranking because they can lead to unauthorized code execution in cases where attackers can control the overwritten memory space outside the targeted buffer and can redirect a function pointer to their malicious code

CompTIA source:
An attack in which data goes past the boundary of the destination buffer and begins to corrupt adjacent memory. This can allow the attacker to crash the system or execute arbitrary code.
___
This bug can lead to system errors on its own, but a deliberate attack can result in the loss of important data, system downtime, or the execution of malicious code.
taken from:
https://www.n-able.com/blog/buffer-overflow-vulnerabilities-protection
_____
Based on these statements, answer should be A

Buffer overflows can affect all types of software. They typically result from malformed inputs or failure to allocate enough space for the buffer. If the transaction overwrites executable code, it can cause the program to behave unpredictably and generate incorrect results, memory access errors, or crashes.
.Answer is A

I'd go with A. stack over-flow attack, seems to fit this definition of buffer-overflow.

To exploit a buffer overflow vulnerability, the attacker passes data that deliberately overfills the buffer (an area of memory) that the application reserves to store the expected data. There are three principal exploits:
Stack overflow—the stack is an area of memory used by a program subroutine. It includes a return address, which is the location of the program that called the subroutine. An attacker could use a buffer overflow to change the return address, allowing the attacker to run arbitrary code on the system. Two examples of this are the Code Red worm, which targeted Microsoft's IIS web server (version 5) and the SQLSlammer worm, which targeted Microsoft SQL Server® 2000.

References:
COM501B - The Official CompTIA Study Guide 
https://www.sans.org/reading-room/whitepapers/threats/paper/481
https://www.csoonline.com/article/3513477/what-is-a-buffer-overflow-and-how-hackers-exploit-these-vulnerabilities.html
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arbitrary_code_execution

Buffers are sequential memory partitions set aside for storage or moving data within a program. However, they can only store an allotted amount of data, and programs without bounds checking run the risk of writing data that exceeds the storage capacity of a given buffer into that space. This bug can lead to system errors on its own, but a deliberate attack can result in the loss of important data, system downtime, or the execution of malicious code.

A buffer overflow occurs when a program or process attempts to write more data to a fixed length block of memory (a buffer), than the buffer is allocated to hold. By sending carefully crafted input to an application, an attacker can cause the application to execute arbitrary code, possibly taking over the machine. Seems like it is A based off this definition
I will go with A. It is more accurate and the keywords fit better.

ALL I know is A) DO NOT TRUST MelvinJohn, and B) a primary concern of, mayhaps the main concern of, Buffer Overflows is that it busts open memory spots in which hackers can run their own injected code, scripts or commands!!

Instead, all of them states that a buffer overflow overwrites memory. A TPM has a memory (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trusted_Platform_Module) that can be overwritten by a buffer overflow which may lead privilege escalation (https://www.csoonline.com/article/3513477/what-is-a-buffer-overflow-and-how-hackers-exploit-these-vulnerabilities.html).
B is correct - Buffers are widespread in operating systems (OS) code, so it is possible to make attacks that perform privilege escalation and gain unlimited access to the computer's resources.
i think A is the correct Answare .

comments.content: If you're not sure what the answer is, don't provide a response. I'm so sick of seeing so many people post incorrect answers. Furthermore, if you're not sure, just say so. Don't write up a response as if it's fact.

discussion.content:
A not B - "TPM" actually protects against buffer overflow. The Trusted Platform Module (TPM) is a hardware device that will authenticate the code modules contained in the Basic Input/Output System (BIOS) of a computer to ensure that the Computer System starts in a trustworthy state. This device can also protect against Memory Management attacks including Buffer Overflows and Memory Pointer attacks.
https://www.igi-global.com/chapter/secure-bootstrapping-using-the-trusted-platform-module/188522

B. Buffers are widespread in operating system code, so it is possible to make attacks that perform privilege escalation. But buffer overwrites ususally result in erratic program behavior, including memory access errors, incorrect results, and crashes.

Seems that "B" is a correct answer. TPM has memory that can be overwritten
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trusted_Platform_Module
TPN override does not exist
I would go with A as well, been researching TPN and I can't find anything on "TPN override". A actually makes sense when you research buffer overflow.
Privilege escalation yes, TPN override? What is that? What’s TPN? A also makes sense so go with that one instead

questions.question_text: A buffer overflow can result in:

discussion.content: Data classification is broadly defined as the process of organizing data by relevant categories so that it may be used and protected more efficiently. On a basic level, the classification process makes data easier to locate and retrieve. Data classification is of particular importance when it comes to risk management, compliance, and data security.

questions.question_text:
A company has a data classification system with definitions for `Private` and `Public`. The company's security policy outlines how data should be protected based on type. The company recently added the data type `Proprietary`.
Which of the following is the MOST likely reason the company added this data type?

choices.D: Expanded authority of the privacy officer

discussion.content:
This question was on the test. Taken Jan 24, 2020 
Provided answer is correct.

A. Unsecured DNS responses can be forgeries that can redirect traffic destined for trusted services to malicious sites. 
Internet users can be protected from attacks like this by deploying DNSSEC,

The Domain Name System Security Extensions (DNSSEC) is a set of specifications that extend the DNS protocol by adding cryptographic authentication for responses received from authoritative DNS servers

questions.question_text: Users are attempting to access a company's website but are transparently redirected to another websites. The users confirm the URL is correct. Which of the following would BEST prevent this issue in the future?
